text: :+1::skin-tone-3::+1::skin-tone-3::+1::skin-tone-3:
are there any good references/resources for modeling and create new variables using python? or is there a lecture we did a lot of modeling I can re-visit?

elements.text: nevermind, the kaggle notebooks will do...

text: the lectures of week 4 should be helpful here. With "creating new variables" you mean feature engineering?

elements.text: the lectures of week 4 should be helpful here. With "creating new variables" you mean feature engineering?

text:
we did a lot of wrangling type steps at the end of the first week of the course, also in your first project, the start of week 2 and 4- but a lot of these skills are from python (generic) lessons and techniques, like creating functions, using lambda, using map+apply, filter and reduce, str operations, or very helpfully, how to use if statements or case statements to categorise values into buckets. this is in the pre work too. at the end of week 4 you had a lot of practice with filtering, subsets and aggregations. all solutions are published.
 in general, once you have in mind what you want to do with a common, it may be about you experimenting and finding the easiest path to get to that result - whether via a function, a loop, a case statement etc

example which may be helpful for you - lets take column yr_renovated. We might conclude that the interesting thing is *whether* a renovation happened or not, not when it took place. one method might be to create a function which converts the year of renovation to a truefalse boolean
```def truefalse(x):
    if x == 0:
        n = 0
    elif x > 0:
        n = 1
    return n

df_drop['yr_renovated']=df_drop['yr_renovated'].apply(truefalse)```
there are probably half a dozen ways to achieve the same thing for this column, including pandas replace, using regex, or a loc query - one reason to keep the true/false function generic is the same function be applied to other features:
```df['sqft_basement']=df['sqft_basement'].apply(truefalse)```
so now we have a flag for ‘has a basement’ and a flag for ‘has been renovated’

elements.text:
we did a lot of wrangling type steps at the end of the first week of the course, also in your first project, the start of week 2 and 4- but a lot of these skills are from python (generic) lessons and techniques, like creating functions, using lambda, using map+apply, filter and reduce, str operations, or very helpfully, how to use if statements or case statements to categorise values into buckets. this is in the pre work too. at the end of week 4 you had a lot of practice with filtering, subsets and aggregations. all solutions are published.
 in general, once you have in mind what you want to do with a common, it may be about you experimenting and finding the easiest path to get to that result - whether via a function, a loop, a case statement etc

example which may be helpful for you - lets take column yr_renovated. We might conclude that the interesting thing is
whether
a renovation happened or not, not when it took place. one method might be to create a function which converts the year of renovation to a truefalse boolean

there are probably half a dozen ways to achieve the same thing for this column, including pandas replace, using regex, or a loc query - one reason to keep the true/false function generic is the same function be applied to other features:
df['sqft_basement']=df['sqft_basement'].apply(truefalse)
so now we have a flag for ‘has a basement’ and a flag for ‘has been renovated’

attachments.title: Binning Data with Pandas qcut and cut
attachments.text: Pandas qcut and cut are both used to bin continuous values into discrete buckets or bins. This article explains the differences between the two commands and how to use each.

text:
`%matplotlib inline`

tells jupyter notebook to display the plots directly in its frontend, and not for example open an extra pop up window like it happened in your case
